In 1843, Dickens was horrified by reading
a Government report. It was, in fact, the

22.text:
second parliamentary report - The Parliamentary
Commission on the Employment of Women and

29.text:
Children, showing the horrific conditions
under which very young children were made

35.text:
to work under ground or to work tremendously
long hours in appalling conditions in factories.

41.text:
Dickens read this and he described himself
as being “perfectly stricken down by it”

48.text:
and he determined that he would strike, as
he said, “the heaviest blow in my power”

55.text:
on behalf of these victims of the Industrial
Revolution and in October 1843, he was giving

68.text:
a talk in Manchester. It was in the course
of giving this talk in this large industrial

74.text:
city, that the idea came to him that the best
thing he could do by way of calling public

82.text:
attention to the horror of this report, would
be by writing a story, rather than an article

92.text:
- “Something that would strike the heaviest
blow in my power”, as he said, “something

97.text:
that would come down with sledgehammer force”
- and this was the conception of the Christmas

103.text:
Carol, beginning, of course, with the conception
of Scrooge - that wonderful name, Scrooge

109.text:
- a combination of screw and gouge.
The idea of Scrooge as the ultimate miser,

119.text:
the ultimate loner, who had no feelings for
the rest of humanity, except just for how

129.text:
much money he would make out of them. Then
he had the concept of the three spirits - the

137.text:
Spirit of Christmas Past, Christmas Present
and Christmas Future - by which, in one night

143.text:
- the night of Christmas Eve, Scrooge was
to be converted from his extreme misanthropy

152.text:
to great benevolence and love of humanity.
Scrooge is visited by three ghosts - The Ghost

159.text:
of Christmas Past, takes him back into his
childhood and his young manhood, shows him

170.text:
the suffering that he himself underwent as
a child. There's a particularly poignant scene

176.text:
where he's left alone in this barren, horrible
schoolroom, while all the other children have

182.text:
gone home for the Christmas holidays and Dickens
writes, ‘Scrooge sat down and wept to see

189.text:
him his former self as he had used to be.’
He begins with pity for himself, then he's

195.text:
shown further visions which make him very
uncomfortable about his past, his engagement

200.text:
to a beautiful young girl and then the girl
breaking off the engagement and Scrooge, in

207.text:
the present, as it were, is horrified to see
himself becoming in the past, more and more

216.text:
miserly. Then the second visitor is the Ghost
of Christmas Present - this great, jolly giant

226.text:
sitting on a great mound of turkeys and Christmas
puddings and so forth, and he shows Scrooge

237.text:
the home life of his own poor clerk, whom
he pays starvation wages to - 15 shillings

244.text:
a week - and Bob Cratchit has to keep his
family of several children - including, of

250.text:
course, the crippled child, Tiny Tim - and
he has to keep them on this meagre wage. But

257.text:
the Ghost of Christmas Present, shows Scrooge
the family happiness at Christmas and Scrooge

264.text:
is shown even Bob Cratchit, who is a very
devoted and faithful employee, despite the

271.text:
terrible way Scrooge treats him, even raises
a glass to toast Mr. Scrooge. Scrooge is particularly

278.text:
concerned with the crippled child, Tiny Tim,
and he says to the Ghost of Christmas Present,

283.text:
tell me if Tiny Tim will live, and the Ghost
of Christmas Present says, well, if things

288.text:
don't change, then he will not be here for
another Christmas - he will die. And Scrooge

295.text:
is filled with pity. He has this nostalgia
first of all about his own past and before

303.text:
he became corrupt, as it were, then pity for
the Cratchits in the present and then the

308.text:
third - and most, the most frightening, of
course, of the ghosts of the one who doesn't

313.text:
speak - is the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come
- this dark shadow who shows Scrooge visions

321.text:
of the horrible, bleak, desolate death of
an unnamed man, who has cut himself off from

331.text:
all humanity and dies in solitude and is buried
in a very horrible grave in a London churchyard.

342.text:
And Scrooge is made to read the name on that
tombstone which, of course, is Scrooge. So,

351.text:
the third great component is fear, so there's
nostalgia, pity and fear and these things

356.text:
work on Scrooge to convert him so that when
he wakes up the next morning, it hasn't been

362.text:
three different nights, as he thinks - it's
all happened in one night. He has been converted,

368.text:
of course, from this horrible old miser to
one of the most benevolent and loving and

377.text:
outgoing of all possible human beings. And
this is the very well-known story of the Christmas

385.text:
Carol, which gives us this wonderful story
about change - how we can all change and become

Dickens said that he composed it in a kind of frenzy, walking about the black streets
of London night after night, composing this

408.text:
story in his mind, getting it written in time
for publication just immediately after Christmas

416.text:
1843. He wanted it to be a very attractive
little book, so he wanted his publishers to

425.text:
spare no expense - this included coloured
illustrations - hand painted illustrations,

431.text:
which was, of course, enormously expensive,
so that there was a contradiction there - I

436.text:
mean, Dickens wanted the book to reach the
poorest readers, but it would be impossible

442.text:
for the publishers to publish it at less than
five shillings, which was an enormous sum,

448.text: of course, for a working class family to afford.

The illustrator was the very distinguished and famous artist, John Leech, who was the
leading illustrator on the great comic magazine,

465.text:
Punch, and a very very close friend of Dickens.
One of the most powerful illustrations is

473.text:
the illustration of the terrible children
- they're just called Ignorance and Want,

480.text:
with whom the Ghost of Christmas Present confronts
Scrooge at the end of that section of the

486.text:
Carol - just before the Ghost of Christmas
Present - having shown him the Cratchit's

491.text:
dinner, having shown him all the happiness
and joy of his nephew's Christmas party, the

500.text:
Ghost of Christmas Present is about to leave
him. When he notices these rather claw-like

507.text:
feet, skin and bone, as it were - sticking
out from under the robes of the ghost, who

513.text:
then reveals these two terrible children - wolfish,
scowling, desperate - the Ghost of Christmas

520.text:
Present tells Scrooge, beware of these children
and all of their degree. He's hinting at some

527.text:
terrible outbreak of revolution and so on
and this was very much a fear of the 1840s

533.text:
- the hungry 40s as they were known - that
there might occur in England, some kind of

538.text:
revolution, as there had occurred in France
in the previous century and what is very interesting

544.text:
is that Leech - this is not in the text - he
adds this himself, the background to this

551.text:
scene, where Scrooge confronts these two children,
is factory chimneys - factories. The scene's

557.text:
supposed to take place in London, not in Manchester,
but Leech, mindful I suppose, or having talked

563.text:
to Dickens about the horror of the report
of the exploitation of children in mines and

570.text:
manufacturers, does have these factory chimneys
behind, which is in this scene - which is

577.text:
very telling, I think. Anyway, the thing was
written in just a few weeks and it was published,

588.text:
sold out immediately and was a huge, huge
success. It was reviewed everywhere and universally

598.text:
praised. Thackeray, Dickens's great rival
as a novelist, said in his review of the Christmas

605.text:
Carol, “it seems to me a national benefit
and to every man and woman who reads it, a

618.text:
It sold one edition after another. Of course, was put on the stage, Dickens couldn't control
this - I mean, there was no copyright protection

628.text:
in those days, so that dramatists were free
to seize on the work of novelists and turn

635.text:
them into plays and put them on the stage
and I think there were about five different

640.text:
versions of the Carol running at the - at
different London theatres, within weeks of

646.text:
the publication. He had hoped that the Carol
would earn him a great deal of money but,

651.text:
in fact, the costs of production were so enormous
that his profit in the end was very little.

657.text:
He could do nothing to stop the pirates, who
he tried - he went to law to stop the pirated

665.text:
versions of the Carol, but because copyright
laws were so weak in those days, he couldn't

670.text:
do anything about it and he lost the case
and as I've said before, he couldn't do anything

676.text:
about all the dramatisations. So, he had the
mortification of seeing lots and lots of people

681.text:
making lots and lots of money out of the Carol,
but he himself not at all making as much as

689.text:
he thought. However, it did hugely increase
the intensity of that love affair that was

698.text:
the most important in Dickens's life - that
love affair between himself and his public,

705.text:
that relationship that he called personally
affectionate and like no other man's - and

711.text:
the Carol contributed hugely, of course, to
this.
